subject: Add POST and DELETE in MetricReportDefinitions
commitMessage:
Add POST and DELETE in MetricReportDefinitions

Added POST action in MetricReportDefinitions node to allow user
to add new MetricReportDefinition. Using minimal set of
MetricReportDefinition parameters from user bmcweb converts it to
DBus call "AddReport" to Telemetry that serves as a backend
for Redfish TelemetryService.
Added DELETE request in MetricReportDefinitions node to allow user
to remove report from Telemetry.
Added conversion from string that represents duration format into
its numeric equivalent.
Added unit tests for conversion from and to Duration format.

Tested:
 - Tested using witherspoon image on QEMU
 - Verified POST action in different cases:
   - all parameters are provided, new report is added to collection
   - some parameters are missing or invalid, user gets response with
     description of the issue
 - Verified that reports are removed on DELETE request
 - Verified that on invalid DELETE request user receives response
   with error
 - Verified time_utils::fromDurationString()
 - Succesfully passed RedfishServiceValidator.py

Signed-off-by: Wludzik, Jozef <jozef.wludzik@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Krzysztof Grobelny <krzysztof.grobelny@intel.com>
Change-Id: I2fed96848594451e22fde686f8c066d7770cc65a

Patch Set 20:

(2 comments)

Patch Set 20:

(30 comments)

I can't help but notice that the author is proceeding on before fixing the issues with the old commits.  This will cause significant rework in the future.  If the author is ok with that, and the merge timelines it pushes out, I have no problem, but please understand it will take much longer to merge in the long run.

I've made it about halfway through the patchset, and frankly, in my opinion, the author needs to look at it again.  Before doing the rewrite (as that's what it will likely take to get this into passing shape) the author really needs to look at:
1. The openbmc contribution and coding guidelines for c++.
2. The specific rules around bmcweb coding.

This patchset contains numerous cases of:
1. overly complex code.
2. unneeded intermediate data structures and algorithmic lethargy.
3. Insecure coding practices.

As is, this patchset is nowhere near the level it would need to be to be merged, and considering the level of rewrite that needs to take place, there's not a lot of point in reviewing it until the above happens.  With that said, I have 30 comments below that might get you started.  Realistically I only made it through about half of the patch.

Patch Set 20:

(3 comments)

Patch Set 20:

(8 comments)

Patch Set 20:

(3 comments)

Patch Set 20:

> Patch Set 20:
> 
> (30 comments)
> 
> I can't help but notice that the author is proceeding on before fixing the issues with the old commits.  This will cause significant rework in the future.  If the author is ok with that, and the merge timelines it pushes out, I have no problem, but please understand it will take much longer to merge in the long run.
> 
> I've made it about halfway through the patchset, and frankly, in my opinion, the author needs to look at it again.  Before doing the rewrite (as that's what it will likely take to get this into passing shape) the author really needs to look at:
> 1. The openbmc contribution and coding guidelines for c++.
Correct me if I'm wrong but it seems that https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md is lacking any guidelines in matters mostly pointed out by your review.

> 2. The specific rules around bmcweb coding.
Are the rules for bmcweb specified or it's just a common knowledge coming from experience? If its coming only from experience please don't put recursive dependency on that, just teach us :)

> 
> This patchset contains numerous cases of:
> 1. overly complex code.
> 2. unneeded intermediate data structures and algorithmic lethargy.
> 3. Insecure coding practices.
> 
> As is, this patchset is nowhere near the level it would need to be to be merged, and considering the level of rewrite that needs to take place, there's not a lot of point in reviewing it until the above happens.  With that said, I have 30 comments below that might get you started.  Realistically I only made it through about half of the patch.

You've pointed out some areas for improvements (especially in handling time format conversion) and that's fine. For the other comments it's in most cases matter of micro-optimizations and coding style preferences (inlining vs utilizing meta-functions).

I would kindly suggest limiting using this kind of definitive statements. Your opinion about maturity level and 'needing to be rewritten' should be rather based on consensus between contributors, maintainers and community. Given your deep experience, your comments are very welcome, but I believe more friendly approach would be more beneficial for effective collaboration.

> Patch Set 20:
> 
> > Patch Set 20:
> > 
> > (30 comments)
> > 
> > I can't help but notice that the author is proceeding on before fixing the issues with the old commits.  This will cause significant rework in the future.  If the author is ok with that, and the merge timelines it pushes out, I have no problem, but please understand it will take much longer to merge in the long run.
> > 
> > I've made it about halfway through the patchset, and frankly, in my opinion, the author needs to look at it again.  Before doing the rewrite (as that's what it will likely take to get this into passing shape) the author really needs to look at:
> > 1. The openbmc contribution and coding guidelines for c++.
> Correct me if I'm wrong but it seems that https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md is lacking any guidelines in matters mostly pointed out by your review.

To quote the top of that page:
'''
1. Code should be clear and concise.
2. Code should be written with modern practices.
3. Code should be performant.
'''

Most of what I'm suggesting falls into those broad themes (although this patchset seems to do pretty well on #2.  I only included it for completeness).

> 
> > 2. The specific rules around bmcweb coding.
> Are the rules for bmcweb specified or it's just a common knowledge coming from experience? If its coming only from experience please don't put recursive dependency on that, just teach us :)


bmcwebs DEVELOPING.md contains the broad strokes of the rules and themes specific to webserver development, but might not be 100% complete/up to date.  If you find comments that I've made that aren't covered by one of the documents/themes, lets get those pointed out, and a patchset put up to add them.  I already realized that we didn't really document the "inline your URLS for auditability" rule, so I can push a change to get that in.  Most people followed the previous patterns, so it wasn't an issue in the past.  A lot of the specifics around which functions throw, which functions block, which functions return error codes, and how to write secure code come from reading the docs of the standard library, libc, beast, or boost, and looking at other bmcweb examples that do similar things.  I'm happy to teach where I'm able (hence why I did a pretty in depth code review), but authors really need to take it upon themselves to look around that the surrounding code and read the documentation that maintainers and developers have written, then follow the style, format, and handling of the code that we already know works,  as well as ping the maintainer and community (maybe you did that privately?) if they want to embark down a completely new path than what is already basically a solved problem, like posting a dbus interface to a redfish one, and vice versa.  If you get stuck, post questions to the mailing list.

> 
> > 
> > This patchset contains numerous cases of:
> > 1. overly complex code.
> > 2. unneeded intermediate data structures and algorithmic lethargy.
> > 3. Insecure coding practices.
> > 
> > As is, this patchset is nowhere near the level it would need to be to be merged, and considering the level of rewrite that needs to take place, there's not a lot of point in reviewing it until the above happens.  With that said, I have 30 comments below that might get you started.  Realistically I only made it through about half of the patch.
> 
> You've pointed out some areas for improvements (especially in handling time format conversion) and that's fine. For the other comments it's in most cases matter of micro-optimizations and coding style preferences (inlining vs utilizing meta-functions).
> 

"micro-optimizations and coding style preferences."  You forgot security issues, of which there are a few.   Yep, and these optimizations (I wouldn't call them micro) are the reason bmcweb had a faster response time, startup time, and binary footprint than most of the other webservers that it went head to head with in the OpenBMC redfish working group, and is one of the main reasons it's on master as the default, whereas the 4 others aren't.  Also, keep in mind, that some of the optimizations are intended to force a hard bound on memory usage to avoid crashes.  I'm not sure what platform you're using (I'm guessing 2500/2600 with 512MB of ram) but this server runs on systems with significantly less CPU compute, and RAM, while still needing to operate with reasonable performance, and not run the system out of memory.
Most of the coding style preferences come from reading lots and lots of code reviews in this space, and understanding what patterns tend to produce bugs and on master, and what patterns tend to be easy to review,  and that authors tend to get right on the first try.  Rework takes significant effort, so anything that can be done to avoid that upfrom is worthwhile.


> I would kindly suggest limiting using this kind of definitive statements. Your opinion about maturity level and 'needing to be rewritten' should be rather based on consensus between contributors, maintainers and community. Given your deep experience, your comments are very welcome, but I believe more friendly approach would be more beneficial for effective collaboration.

Keep in mind, this is my opinion as the former maintainer of this project, the person that wrote a lot of the bmcweb HTTP core, seen and fixed many bmcweb bugs, and have reviewed hundreds of bmcweb patches.  Of course people are free to have their own opinions, and I will happily listen if others are willing to take an in-depth look at this patch and disagree with me;  Thusfar, I haven't seen a lot of the community do that.  I'm also no longer the bmcweb maintainer, so my opinions are just that, opinions, and do not block the commits from master if James believes I'm out of line here (note, he disagrees with me a lot).  I don't believe I made any comments about the maturity of the author.  If you took that as an offense, I apologize, that was not the intent.  My intent was to focus on the technical capabilities and deficiencies of this specific patch series.

To be clear, do you think this patch is ready to merge into master without a large percentage of it changing?  If so, I'd love to hear why, as I think I've laid out a lot of maintainability problems (both micro and macro) with this patch as is that (if completed) will result in significant portions of it changing.

I dislike making broad statements like the above, but I wanted to make clear that there is a reorganization of the code that needs to occur, and the inline comments I've made alone would not bring this patchset up to where it needs to be.

Done
Shouldn't this be simply char, not char*?
It is simpler to pass a pointer then a variable.

myfunction(char c);
is simpler, and easier to get functionally correct than
myfunction(const char* c)

With that said, if you want to use a full string as input, which (in my opinon) will be more complicated, modern coding guidelines would say to use a string view, or at a minimum pointer and a length.  I'm happy with either, but null terminated strings on api boundaries aren't really modern.

It should be noted, you've also forgot to check it against nullptr.
Done

How is possible that std::strtol is less efficient then your proposition? std::strtol always check if actual pointer is null so it is safe and it verify more other errors such overflow on int variable. Implementing own parser sounds like reinventing a wheel.

lots of things make it better:
1. strtol allows negative numbers, which in the strtol case you've failed to handle.
2. the above parser handles errors (bad/unexpected characters, ect), which your current implementation does not.
3. strtol does handle overflow, but your code doesn't check for it properly.
4. (optional)The above parser could be written to operate directly on a std::chrono::milliseconds object, and parse the entire string in one shot (although I haven't written it here), and avoid all intermediates.

The parser above is IMO, the simplest way to implement all of the above, as it would lead to very little code.  I never said you couldn't do it with strtol, and if that's what you want to do, by all means, but make sure that you've handled all degenerate and error cases.  Assume that a fuzzer will be run on it (because people do), or run a fuzzer of your own (if you want to learn, this would be a great side project for you).

If you want to do it with std library approaches, that's a totally valid solution, it's just harder to get right.
 https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/from_chars
is probably what you want.

Could not used std::from_chars for floating point. I am still using stof but with c_str() to make sure that passed string is null terminated.
About the overflow or negative value, we can add a support but it will only display an error message for developer. For user it is meaningless from my point of view.

I'd prefer you avoided floating point entirely here, as it significantly reduces the attack surface, and makes the implementation more correct.

Once you support the error, you will pass the error code back to the user.  Today, the implementation blindly accepts invalid things, and gives no indication there was an error.

Okay, we will review it again. Is there any range check in readJson (not overflow check)? What if user provide a very long string in request? Is there any limitation for payload from user in bmcweb? Thanks in advance

Anyway this discussion already exists:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/32536/20/redfish-core/include/utils/validate_params_length.hpp#3

Please, answer to it. Thanks in advance

"Is there any range check in readJson (not overflow check)?"

No, we expect the dbus interface on the daemon side to impose whatever size and range checks it needs, and return appropriate error codes.

In theory, readJson should support using something like boost::safe_numerics::safe as input, but that's a much bigger discussion and could be had a project level.

"What if user provide a very long string in request?"
Depending on what limit you run over, you might get an HTTP 400, if you go over the request size limit, or you might get a DBus error if you go over the message size limit.  If you go over an arbitrary property/method input limit, it's expected that the receiving dbus daemon return an appropriate error code.

"Is there any limitation for payload from user in bmcweb?"
Yes, there are several, but once a user is logged the limit is fairly large, given there are use cases with large payloads send to dbus.

I think what you want here is a PropertyValueNotInList error.

"Indicates that a property was given the correct value type but the value of that property was not supported.  This values not in an enumeration"

While this isn't technically an enumeration, I believe it's the closest match redfish has to what you need today.  Also, we've used it in other similar situations.
Type exists in the redfish registries. You can check it by youreslf: https://redfish.dmtf.org/registries/Base.1.8.1.json

For type mismatch there is another message PropertyValueTypeError. Anyway I will add a PropertyValueIncorrect to bmcweb for future use

PropertyValueFormatError: Indicates that a property was given the correct value type but the value of that property was not supported
PropertyValueIncorrect: Indicates that the requested write of a property value could not be completed, because of an incorrect value of the property. Examples include values that do not match a regular expression requirement or passwords that do not match the implementation constraints.

PropertyValueFormatError and PropertyValueIncorrect can be used interchangeably in some cases.

Sweeet!  Didn't know they added that one.  Yes, that's the thing to use.

Now that this is simplified, I just noticed, none of the things have range checks, so as is, this would accept something like

P1DT1234H5678M0.0S

Where I would expect 1234 to be range checked, as there are only 24 hours in a day, and 5678 to be range checked, as there are only 60 minutes in an hour.
Duration format allows to put higher value then the specific time range. It allows us to translate PT48H to P2D.

I just read the spec a little bit.  It looks like you're actually allowed to use decimal points in any field.  The example wikipedia uses is P0.5Y https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601

which should be equal to 182.5 days.  It looks like this implementation doesn't handle that yet.  Also, should we add years to the implementation just for completeness? (even though it's unlikely we'd use it).  I could see a user using something like P0.1Y if they wanted 10 reports per year.

We do not handle it because we follow duration specified by Redfish that is based on ISO 8601. Redfish drops the years and months from their format to avoid a complex implementation that matches a standard. Redfish specify they format according to following pattern:
P[dD][T[hH][mM][s[.f]S]]
It uses only decimal points in seconds. It does not allow decimal points for other fields.
http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DSP0266_1.11.0.html#duration-values

This seems to imply that the designators are required to exist in order, but looking at the redfish spec here:
http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DSP0266_1.11.0.html#duration-values

It claims the format is:
P[dD][T[hH][mM][s[.f]S]]

Which makes each element optional, and that strings like P10M are valid.  Unfortunately, I don't think this implementation handles that properly.

It handles such cases thanks to `or` operation. You can try it by yourself

This looks like it's trying to handle overflow, but it's really tough to determine what it's doing.  Can it be cleaned up some?

Yes, it is not straightforward and took a lot of testing activities to find out the best check for overflow. 
First you have to check overflow after conversion from one chrono::duration type to another.
Second you have to check if value from v (that is long int) fits in the possible maximum range that you can convert from one duration type (ex. hours) to std::chrono::milliseconds. If you omit this check you get smaller value that fits in milliseconds.
In the latest patchset I moved std::chrono::duration_cast<T>(std::chrono::milliseconds::max()).count() to auto maxConversionRange to better reflect it.
@Ed Tanous, just a reminder. Please respond.
Great.  I think I understand.  I'll take a look at the latest patchset and respond there.
